course.subject: HUMA
course.name: The Making of the Modern World: Renaissance to the Present
course.description: This course surveys the major ideas, political developments and cultural movements in European societies from the renaissance to the present, providing students with foundational and thematic knowledge of European history, as well as an understanding of the ways that European politics, culture and economy have shaped through encounters with non-European societies -- through cultural and commercial exchange, imperialism and de-colonization, Cold War rivalries and globalization.

reviews.author: winner17
reviews.title: Derman is super nice
reviews.comment_content:
Course Description

This course surveys the major ideas, political developments, and cultural movements inEuropean societies from the Renaissance to the collapse of Communism, and beyond. It aims to provide undergraduate students with foundational and thematic knowledge ofEuropean history, as well as an understanding of the ways that European politics, culture, and economy have been shaped through encounters with non-European societiesâ€”through cultural and commercial exchange, imperialism and decolonization, Cold War rivalries, and globalization. The course readings explore the ways that political, social, technological, and economic developments affected Europeansâ€™ ability to project power, both within the borders of the modern state and beyond it, and considers the sources and limitations of that power. The course is aimed at students from all backgrounds; no prior acquaintance with history is presupposed.
reviews.comment_teaching: Derman is a really, really good professor. He explains his ideas well, and he always give thorough answers to all of his students. He speaks slowly because he wants to make sure that people understand what he's saying. DO NOT HESITATE to go to him or the TA if you're confused about something. They're always happy to help.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is okay. As long as you try your best in the presentation and take notes during his lectures, you'll be fine. Everything that will appear on the exams are all mentioned in his lectures, so really listen well and ask questions if you're confused about something. There are required readings but I didn't go through them because Derman had already explained everything very clearly.
reviews.comment_workload: You've got a midterm, a presentation, a final exam, and an essay. They're all doable. This is definitely a decent course for people who like to write. But if you're not big on philosophy or writing, you might find the workload annoying.

reviews.author: prolapse
reviews.title: Pretty ok course but depends on your interest and knowledge of history
reviews.comment_content:
European history 1500-1933 A.D.
Should have included up till 1991 but professor didn't have a plan for all of his lectures which wasted time.
As a history enthusiast, the content is fun but do not expect much depth as it its mostly a summary of each century with powerpoints of most major European events with photos that take up each slide and long synopses that make it look like it was made by a high school student.
The lessons felt like high school DSE where there was no discussion and you just listened to the teacher who probably read a script which was mostly pasted on a powerpoint slide.
Attendance taken every lesson but luckily signature not needed.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Horrendous and unprepared
The man has tremendous knowledge of European history and taught for 40 years yet some local high school history teachers can do better.
He speaks exceptionally slow which makes me wanna fall asleep, taking him all lesson to finish half a slide which probably only takes a few minutes.
Discussion in class is also a big no no which makes his classes supremely boring as everything is just condensed while he reads his script.
Big credit to the TA tho, without him, this course would probably not even be on canvas.
reviews.comment_grading:
Essay (20%)
Participation (10%)
Map Quiz (10%)
2 Content Quizzes (30%)
Final Examination (30%)

Received an A- but mostly would attribute to passion.
Need to work harder on studying content quizzes as its harder and unpredictable than exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
Acceptable and light compared to other huma courses.
1000 word Essay on the novel "All Quiet on the Western Front" lots of reading also old movies and adaptions depending on the questions.
Many readings but personally have not read them as ppt and study guide more important for quizzes.

reviews.author: å¿«æ¨‚è‚¥ä»”
reviews.title: Best Professor in the UST
reviews.comment_content:
Feb. 1: Introduction
Feb. 5: The age of exploration
Feb. 8: The Renaissance
Feb. 19: The military revolution
Feb. 22: The Reformation
Feb. 26: The struggle for supremacy
Mar. 1: Absolutism and its alternatives
Mar. 5: The Scientific Revolution
Mar. 8: Europe and the early modern world
Mar. 12: The age of reason
Mar. 15: Revolutionary Europe
Mar. 22: The Industrial Revolution
Mar. 26: The age of ideologies
Mar. 29: Globalization and imperialism
Apr. 9: The First World War
Apr. 12: The Soviet experience
Apr. 16: The postwar settlement(part I)
Apr. 19: National Socialism
Apr. 23: The Second World War
Apr. 26: The postwar settlement (part II)
Apr. 30: The wonder years
May 3: Decolonization
May 7: The collapse of Communism
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Derman is one of the most respectable, reliable and lenient teachers I have met in the UST. He is always very patient and willing to answer my questions. He would also arrange an office hour for students before the exam so that students can seek help from him easily. He is super considerate and gentle and the TA is very friendly as well. P.S. They would disclose the scores for every assessment for our references.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance: 10%
Participation: 5% (It is expected that each student in the course participates at least once, either by asking a question, making a comment, or serving as group reporter after a breakout session. Fulfilling this requirement results in a 100% participation grade. Failure to satisfy it results in a 0% participation grade.)
Midterm examination: 25%
Term paper: 30%
Final examination: 30%
(Students will be asked to answer multiple-choice questions and complete a series of identification questions based on the lectures and assigned readings. Identification questions involve a list of several nouns: names/places/events/ideas etc. You will be asked to choose some number of them (e.g. 3 out of 5) to identify. Identifying means answering several questions that I will pose about the meaning or significance of each term. Specific examples will be discussed closer to the examination.)

My scores:
Midterm exam: 96/100 Mean 71.83
Term paper: 94/100
Final exam: 93/100 Mean: 79.33
Attendance: 100/100
Final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: The workload may be a bit heavy for students who are not familiar with European history. Reading the assigned text may not be a must for performing well in the exams, but it is super necessary for writing essays. It is impossible to finish the essay without reading the books.

reviews.author: Telvis
reviews.title: Interesting course for history lovers
reviews.comment_content:
the course focuses from 15th centaury to late 20th centaury
and professor will only give a brief look of each events
1. The age of exploration
2. The Renaissance

reviews.comment_grading:
B
higher than my expectation
Attendance: 10%
Participation: 5%
Midterm examination: 25%
Term paper: 30%
Final examination: 30%

Midterm and Final exam are the same: MC + short writing
reviews.comment_workload:
Acceptable workload
just have some readings
and there is an essay

reviews.author: ywyw
reviews.comment_content: Mainly focuses on the Renaissance period to modern society. If you have some background knowledge in history, it would be quite interesting to discover more things that you didn't know previously. It would be a painful course if you don't like reading.
reviews.comment_teaching: The PowerPoint is the main source for teaching, and the professor elaborates more on the contents on the PowerPoint. He talks slowly and accurately, which makes it much easier to understand the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final grade: A
The grading is fair if you work hard enough throughout the lecture. Attendance is required and you need to turn on your camera if you are participating online.
reviews.comment_workload: Huge workload, need to read around 20 pages on average before each class. Need to write 1 reflection paper and 1 essay.

reviews.author: yoooolanda
reviews.comment_content:
Lots of readings to do and most of them are compulsory.

Content covered European history starting from the Renaissance to the present.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is always patient and enthusiastic to answer your questions.

There is also a zoom session before the test including mid-term and the final.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade if you do hard work during the course-- or stay up late several nights before the test.
By the way, attendance is required and randomly checked in class.
reviews.comment_workload:
The readings count for the majority of the workload.
There is also a 1.reflection paper/2.essay to do on your own.

reviews.author: chillica
reviews.title: Do not leave the readings till the last minute
reviews.comment_content: The course is quite easy to understand and interesting if you have some background in history. The content covers a considerably wide range of content including 13th century exploration, the Industrial Revolution, the two World Wars and all the way up to the cold war. Content revolves around two main areas : the projection of economic and political power, and European colonization. The topic of your papers will be very closely related to this.
reviews.comment_teaching: During lectures, the professor mainly goes through the points stated on the powerpoint but in more detail. There will be a compulsory session for midterm paper checking so there will be time for you to ask the professor questions individually or ask him to clarify or explain his grading.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation - 10%
Midterm exam -20%
Midterm paper - 25%
Final exam- 20%
Final paper - 25%

Grading on papers is quite lenient in my opnion
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload can be very heavy if you leave the readings to the last minute, as you will find that just reading lecture notes is not enough for you to right 2 papers that will be 7 pages long each.

But otherwise, revising for exams wouldn't take you much time if you had attended every lecture.

reviews.title: Remember to spend some time on the readings
reviews.comment_content: Currently a pre-enrolled course for first-year GCS students. As the course name implies, HUMA 2590 offers introductory and fundamental knowledge of European history from the 15th century (with some background information tracing back to earlier centuries) to the end of the Cold War. Throughout the course, several main historical events would be introduced. Students would understand why European societies were regarded as political, cultural and economic powerhouses and how they shaped the development of the modern era; how Europe stood as the center of modernization, ideologies, revolutions, and conflicts; as well as understanding how Europe affected civilizations outside herself through imperialism and globalization. Two macrohistorical questions pertaining to Europe's extensive influence over the globe and the decline of European empires would help students reflect modern and contemporary history in a comparative and theoretical manner. If you have acquired some basic common sense of history, you could easily catch up with the course content. But generally, this course is not too difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Derman is knowledgeable in modern European history, and his research focuses on Germany. While he mainly recited the information on the PowerPoints, he provided some extra details. In the first few weeks of the course, he discussed the readings with us, but he eventually dropped the practice (he probably knew that many of us did not read the readings in advance, and there was not enough time to finish all the lectures if he continued to do that) and just typed some of the arguments in the readings in the lecture notes instead. It is nice of him to officially extend the final paper deadline for two weeks until the final exam. Remember to ask him in case you have encountered anything difficult, and he will endeavor to respond.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation (10%): the instructor randomly selected 8 lessons to let us sign our name on the attendance sheet, which counts for 8%. The other 2% is for the mandatory meeting with the instructor to discuss the midterm paper.

Midterm and final exams (20% for each): 40 multiple-choice questions and 10 map questions (not sure if changes would occur). Questions would include everything that is typed on the PowerPoints and the required readings. Jotting extra notes is unnecessary, but you should thoroughly revise (or recite) the information on the lecture notes. Beware of some questions that would ask you to recall the correct order of events (like the process of the French Revolution and the Holocaust). Main arguments raised in the required readings would also be examined. As for the map questions, the instructor would give you the maps in advance and s/he would offer a list of city and country names that would be tested. I personally find it easy.

Midterm and final papers (25% for each): You have to write two 7-page essays based on the required readings. The topic is related to the aforementioned two macrohistorical questions. Just approach the professor if you have any problems regarding the readings or the essays.

My marks:
Participation: full marks
Midterm exam: 82/100 (mean: 60 or 60-something if I remember right)
Midterm paper: 94/100 (mean: 80-something)
Final exam: 88/100
Final paper: 92/100

Final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: I would say the workload is average as you do need to spend time comprehending the required readings in order to write your essays and prepare for the exams. There is a textbook for this course, but unless you are a beginner in European history or you want to supplement yourself with more historical details, reading the textbook is somewhat unnecessary as studying the required readings and the lecture notes are probably more than enough for dealing with the assessments. Other than that, just remind yourself to attend the lessons.

reviews.author: PimpDaddy
reviews.title: A lot of reading - a lot!
reviews.comment_content: You will learn European history from the Renaissance to the Cold War. You will investigate the influence of colonialism, imperialism, and geopolitics on creating our modern world and its problems. It is a highly useful introduction to understanding just why the world has so many problems. For example, you will learn all about nationalism and make up your own mind about how destructive/beneficial it has been to the world. You are not expected to know anything about history but it is certainly an advantage if you do
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Derman is a nice instructor who has taught this course many times before. He will speak slowly and clearly to ensure you can get all the key information. He does provide PowerPoint slides online but he will emphasise what, out of hundreds of pages of reading, is the important stuff. He is willing to answer questions and tries to make the class engaging every week by holding office hours, Q&As, and group discussion sections.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is a little frustrating. You must hand in 2 essays and complete 2 exams. No homework. He will give broad prompts for the essays and you are expected to write a thoughtful 8 page answer to the question but you are not expected to come up with your own new theories. This essay is largely to prove that you have read the assigned readings, book, and PowerPoint slides. He will grade your essay quite fairly and does not penalise grammatical errors.

The exam, on the other hand, is a grading nightmare. The exam has 3 sections: a map question, a multiple choice section, and a long essay section. For the map question, you will receive a map without country or city names. Identify the countries or cities- easy. The multiple choice questions directly test things from the PowerPoint slides or lectures. So just pick the correct answer - easy. For the long essay, you must pick 4 out of 6 topics (e.g, The Enlightenment or Isaac Newton) and describe it fully. You never know what he is looking for, so you must regurgitate everything you know.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for this course is very high. You will be assigned readings every week. The readings are 1-2  chapters from Modern Civilisations and an extra essay/paper/book chapter that discusses a theme in more detail. This is around 100-200 pages of reading per week. You cannot skip this section because you need the readings to complete the essays and the exams.

reviews.author: BC
reviews.comment_content:
Covered most of the European historic events from the 14th century to Europe today. Most of the contents are given in ppt slides, little notes needed to be jotted in lectures.
One summary sheet with key terms is provided in each lecture for easier understanding.
But you still need a good level of English to cope with a large number of terms.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. is good. He is passionate in this subject. He explains the content well. So, attending lectures definitely helps your understanding. The only shortcoming is that you need time to familiarize with his accent. (He is an Italian with a Hong Kongese wife) Though, his speaking pace is quite slow (also a bit boring sometimes), you can follow the content most of the time.
reviews.comment_grading:
2 in-class quizzes: 10% each
Midterm: 35%
Final: 45%
Quizzes include MC questions and map questions. MC are mostly straight-forward. Map questions are quite difficult for most of the students (as reflected by prof afterwards).
Midterm includes MC questions, map questions and term identifications. Term identifications are straight-forward but you need to memorize word by word.
Final includes all the above question types plus some essay questions. All the course contents are accumulated but most of the essays focus on the syllabus after midterm.
The overall grade is quite good. The amount of a range given seems more than usual.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy workload although there's no assignment. If you don't like European history, you will be in hell.
Prof does not require us to memorize the exact year of events, however map of Europe in different centuries needed to be memorized.
There is also a reading for every lecture, which ranged from 6-16 pages from case to case. These include in the exam syllabus.

reviews.author: kykyw
reviews.comment_grading:
My grade: A

reviews.author: randompeople
reviews.title: SOSC 1350
reviews.comment_content: First half of the course is about Chinaâ€™s political issues such as the Hukou system and political structure. Second half of the course is about Chinaâ€™s social issue (educational system, population issue, work unit)
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite boring but easy to follow. The professor explained the topic quite clear. But he talks a little bit too fast.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fair. Only one midterm and final. Attendance will be counted so make sure you attend every lesson.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is not high. Only one midterm and final exam. There are no assignments. There will be several pop-up quiz during lessons and the marks will be counted. There are required readings for the course and some will be tested in exams.
